Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at my screen, the spreadsheet for the client’s project open in one window, the telemarketing dialer blinking in another. As a colleague, I knew the report I was working on was the last piece before we could deliver to the client—everyone was waiting on me, and the deadline was today. My manager had reminded me twice already that any delay would jeopardize the whole project. But as a telemarketer, today was the final day of the quarter, and we were just shy of our sales target. Management had made it clear: if we didn’t hit the number, there would be no bonuses, and worse, there might be penalties for the whole team. My phone buzzed with reminders from both teams—one urging me to finish the report, the other pushing for more calls. My hands hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, torn between letting down my colleagues or my sales team. The pressure from both sides felt suffocating, and I could feel the weight of their expectations pressing in, demanding a choice I wasn’t ready to make.
